title: Stock Futures Retreat After Three-Day Rally; All three major U.S. stock indexes are on pace to end the week with gains
text:
In premarket trading, a sharp plunge in Snap shares weighed on growth stocks. Snap lost 28% before the opening bell after posting its weakest-ever quarterly sales growth as a public company. Shares of Meta Platforms and Alphabet pulled back 4.8% and 2.9%, respectively. Later Friday, investors will parse earnings reports from companies including Twitter.

The S&P 500, the Dow and the Nasdaq are on pace to end the week in solidly positive territory, offering a respite to investors who have seen their portfolios pummeled this year. One bright spot this week has been a stretch of earnings reports that have given investors confidence to wade in and scoop up beaten-down stocks. Companies including Netflix and IBM have been among those who beat Wall Street expectations, even as firms across all sectors contend with obstacles including a strong dollar and inflationary labor pressures.

This week marked the return of a familiar trade that dominated in recent years: Buying shares of tech companies. The Nasdaq Composite has risen 5.3% this week, based on Thursday's closing prices, outpacing the S&P 500's 3.5% rise. Netflix, Nvidia and Tesla have emerged as among the biggest gainers this week, with shares of all three companies rising 13% or more, through Thursday.

Nonetheless, few investors say they are willing to call a bottom to a selloff that has dragged the S&P 500 down 16% this year. Worries about persistently high inflation, the possibility of a recession and the war in Ukraine remain on the forefront of investors' minds.

"I think investors are fishing for the bottom," said Carsten Brzeski, ING Groep's global head of macro research. But, he said, "I still would be cautious."

Mr. Brzeski noted that next week's meeting of the Federal Reserve, as well as U.S. gross domestic product data, could inject more volatility in the markets.

Investors will continue to keep a close watch on events in Europe, including the continuing uncertainty around the flow of Russian natural gas through the critical Nord Stream pipeline. Brent crude fell 0.3% to $99.19 a barrel Friday.

Traders will also be watching for the ripple effects from the resignation of Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi on Thursday. Italy's benchmark FTSE MIB stock index fell 0.2% Friday.

Elsewhere in Europe, the pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 traded roughly flat. The euro retreated 0.9% against the dollar to $1.0138, raising the possibility that Europe's common currencycould reach parity again.

Investors continued to assess the European Central Bank'slarger-than-expected interest-rate increase on Thursday, as well French and German flash purchasing managers' data for July that came in below expectations.

In the bond market, the yield on the benchmark 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell to 2.844%, down from 2.908% Thursday. Yields fall when bond prices rise.

In Asia, trading was fairly flat. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.1%, while China's Shanghai Composite lost 0.1%. Japan's Nikkei 225 gained 0.4%.
